data.title: Wîhkwêntôwin: Oliver community to petition city council to change neighbourhood name
data.meta_description: Edmonton's most populous neighbourhood has unveiled its choice for a new name.
data.text:
Article content

Edmonton’s most populous neighbourhood has unveiled its choice for a new name.

The Oliver Community League on Tuesday announced that pending city council approval the central neighbourhood will be known as Wîhkwêntôwin (we-kwen-to-win), Cree for “a circle of friends.”

Tuesday’s announcement was the latest step in a years-long process to rename the community after debate over the racist legacy of its namesake, settler politician Frank Oliver. The name was given by Elder Jerry Saddleback and has been approved by the city’s naming committee.

Article content

Oliver Community League president Imran Ahmad said the league sought input from every resident in the neighbourhood and undertook years of consultations before settling on the new name.

“The name change is a big moment,” Ahmad said during the ceremony at the Oliver Exchange building. “I think it’s a step in terms of reconciliation and recognizing the land we’re on.”

He nevertheless hoped little would change about the community he calls home.

“In terms of our day-to-day, I still live in Wîhkwêntôwin the same as I did yesterday, I still go to work here.”

Located west of Downtown between 109 Street and 124 Streets, more Edmontonians call Oliver home than any other single neighbourhood. It is one of the densest neighbourhoods in North America, according to past community league president Robyn Paches, and with towers going up in every direction, one of the city’s fastest growing.

The community was initially called the West End before being rechristened Oliver in 1937, four years after Oliver’s death.

Oliver was a newspaperman and politician who arrived at Fort Edmonton in 1867. He founded the settlement’s first newspaper, the Edmonton Bulletin, and was later elected as a member of Parliament. He served in Wilfrid Laurier’s cabinet as minister of the interior and superintendent of Indian Affairs, where he vehemently opposed non-British and non-white immigration. At one point, he drafted an order banning Black immigrants from entering the country, and also took racist positions regarding Ukrainians, Slavs, French Canadians and Asians.

Article content

Advertisement 3

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

As a newspaper editor, Oliver pushed for First Nations reserves to be sold off and Métis lands to be surrendered for valueless “scrip.” The Oliver Act, which he introduced, allowed reserve lands to be expropriated and Indigenous reserves in or near towns to be removed. He advocated for the removal of the Papaschase band, which resided in what is now southeast Edmonton until the federal government evicted them and auctioned off the land.

Oliver was also an influential booster of Edmonton’s business and political interests and was key in winning support for naming the city the provincial capital. He also played a role in the development of the national parks system, and advocated against conscription during the First World War.

The most recent reappraisal of Oliver’s legacy began in 2017 amid protests around Canada’s 150th anniversary. In June 2020, the Oliver Community League formally asked the city to change its name, initiating a consultation campaign dubbed “Uncover Oliver.”

Some viewed efforts to rename the community with skepticism. Then-Edmonton Journal columnist Paula Simons, for one, said removing Oliver’s name could let the city “off the hook” for its colonial past.

Advertisement 4

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

“Oliver’s story is integral to the story of Edmonton, not in spite of his flaws, but because of them,” she wrote. “We’re a great multicultural city, built on a racist Imperial matrix. We can’t erase that fact. We have to recognize and confront it — and remembering Oliver helps do that.”

Paches said the intent was not to whitewash the city’s history. Exploring Oliver’s legacy was a focus of the campaign, he said.

“It was very educational-first — who was Frank Oliver, and what did he do? We want to make sure that we take that educational point moving forward.”

Ahmad doubted whether the name change would cause people to forget Oliver and what he stood for.

“It’s not like we’re trying to hide it or anything,” he said. “The history is there, as Elder Saddleback mentioned.”

The league said it mailed consultation forms to every address in the community starting in 2022 asking if they supported a name change. Seventy per cent of respondents were in favour, with 30 per cent strongly supporting a change to an Indigenous name.

The process also included a renaming circle made up of Indigenous elders, leaders from the Chinese community and descendants of Black settlers. Paches said he’s proud of the process and thinks it can be “an example for the rest of the world.”

Advertisement 5

Story continues below

This advertisement has not loaded yet, but your article continues below.

Article content

“I don’t think we left any stone unturned,” he said.

The proposed name will go before the city’s executive committee Feb. 7, with debate before the full city council taking place Feb. 20.

The decision to rename specific buildings, businesses and institutions — including Oliver Arena, Oliver Pool, Oliver School and the Oliver Exchange — would be left with their respective decision makers, Ahmad said.

Paches, for his part, said he hopes the idea of a neighbourhood as a “circle of friends” resonates with others as it has with him.

“I was a small town guy, came to the city for the first time when I was 18. I didn’t have anybody, know anybody, and this community really got around me and I have a wonderful support network now. And I think that’s the lived experience of a lot of people here.”

jwakefield@postmedia.com
